description.narrative: Increased national capacity to provide access to effective social welfare systems including skilled workforce and case management, which contributes to Child Protection Systems, Child Protection â€“ Strengthen Families And Communities, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Social protection programmes and systems respond effectively to the rights of the poorest and most vulnerable children and their families, complemented by quality social welfare services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Increased national capacity to provide access to effective social welfare systems including skilled workforce and case management

description.narrative: Through community case management 112,000 children were identified, assessed and referred to relevant services; whereby 27,000 of them received direct support from the committees; 79,000 were assisted to obtain various support services (health, education, food and nutrition, reunification and post reunification follow up). | Status:Met | As-of Date:20/01/2017

title.narrative: of poor and vulnerable children identified by Community Committees and referred to appropriate support services

actual.value: 2016:During the reporting period a total of 95,596 poor and vulnerable children were identified and referred to appropriate services.

title.narrative: % of Community Committees trained on harmonized approach to CCM, child rights (including PSS) and guidelines and provided with start-up grants

actual.value: 2016:43% of districts have trained social action professionals (including through training courses financed by UNICEF and United States Agency for International Development (USAID).
